messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: An earthquake is when the ground shakes a lot.  
Earthquakes break many things. They break bridges too.  
Luckily, bridges do not fall down very often.  
New bridges are strong.  
Engineers know how to build bridges in places with earthquakes.  
They build bridges on land that does not move much.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation and Fidelity Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6767 is below the required 0.75 and the BERTScore of 0.8774 is below the required 0.90.
- The MeaningBERT score of 0.6767 indicates that the paraphrase loses the core message about engineers designing bridges in earthquake zones on areas more resistant to movement.
- The BERTScore of 0.8774 shows key terms like "damage all structures", "modern bridges", and "earthquake zones" were simplified to weaker phrases like "break many things", "new bridges", and "places with earthquakes".
Suggestion: Restore the phrase "damage all structures" to preserve the original emphasis.
Suggestion: Reintroduce "modern bridges" to specify the infrequency of collapse in new designs.
Suggestion: Use "engineers design bridges in earthquake zones on areas more resistant to movement" to maintain technical accuracy.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: We call big shakes of the ground earthquakes.  
Big shakes break all structures.  
They can break bridges too.  
But big shakes do not break modern bridges often.  
Builders learn to design bridges for big shakes.  
They put bridges on ground that does not move much.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.5705 is below the required 0.75, indicating a loss of the core message.
- The term "earthquake zones" is dropped in the rewrite, removing the focus on specific high-risk areas.
- The phrase "areas that are much more resistant to movement" is oversimplified to "ground that does not move much," losing the nuance of engineered resistance.
- The subject "engineers" is changed to "builders," which reduces technical accuracy.
Suggestion: Reintroduce the phrase "earthquake zones," restore "areas that are much more resistant to movement," and use "engineers" to preserve the original meaning.
